description: What a long day of travel!  Must sleep

photos.caption: This is what my brain looks like after 24 hours of continuous travel

description: Just really wanted a slow kickback day and not much honestly planned for BK.  So just tooled around the local streets.

photos.caption: A much needed slow day.  So yeah, you get a black building.
More like Vomitism amiright?

description: The focus of this day was FOOD TOUR!  5 people on the tour + 2 guides.  15 dishes.  Walked around Chinatown sampling a nice array of Thai specialties (primarily street food).  All of it was excellent.  Some of it surprising and a few really incredible dishes.

photos.caption: Mall tour - a massive mall
Bangkok sidewalks are loads of fun
Food tour - kitty not on the menu
Saw all these vines above this alley  - waitaminute, those aren't vines
Food tour:  Thai pork leg stew
Making chive dumplings along the food tour
The bbq'd chive dumplings - very unique and very good
Thai sukiyaki - very good
On the food tour in Chinatown
Was taking this picture of this door and as I shot it this little boy came out from behind it
My favorite dish of the food tour:  green curry. Very subtle, incredible flavors wth just the right spice
Hot (white) pepper stew with crunchy pork - amazing
I was pressured to try the Thai durian and to be fair it was the best durian I've ever had
Food tour - making Thai donuts
Alley in Chinatown lit at night
Street food in Chinatown Mon-Sat - huge crowds and this is the offseason

description: Escaped the creepy weirdness of Bangkok for a calmer place here in Chiang Mai, in northern Thailand.  Got in pretty early but the heat wasn't motivating for touring around.  I went out at 7pm and it had cooled off by at least 10 degrees and few people were around.  This might be the plan (+ early mornings).  Then take refuge during the heat of day.  Had my first Khao Soi from its birth-region and it didn't disappoint.  I might write more about this dish later.  Not sure how long I'll be in CM - winging it at this point.

photos.caption: Khao Soi with chicken - wow
Silly dog at Wat Phra Singh
Wat Phra Singh
Wat Phra Singh with monk walking by - many of them doing monk things whatever monk things are
Wat Phra Singh - night time is best time
Wat Phra Singh - 10 deg cooler and very few people around
Wat Phra Singh
Small street in Chiang Mai
Mango Sticky Rice - a favorite

description: Early morning I was off to tour the local temples (there are many of them).  So few people were at the temples at that hour so that was a big win.  Weather is tolerable in the morning.  By about 9am it starts getting pretty brutal out of the shade.  I will have no updates tomorrow as I'll be on a jungle hike/tour, staying the night at a tribal village.

photos.caption: Tree at Wat Chedi Luang.  It's so weird - there aren't a lot of trees in Chiang Mai, then you see this massive unit of a tree
Wat Chedi Luang - one of many temples at this site
Wat Chedi Luang - interior of a more modern temple
Wat Chedi Luang
Wat Chedi Luang - a 15th century temple - incredible
Elephants on the Wat Chedi Luang temple
I sorely wanted to Bang This Gong
Eddie Van Thailand wails during the solo
Saw a good boy as I peeked thru a gate in Chiang Mai
Back to Wat Phra Singh but inside this time.  They like their big Buddha's here but this is an especially big one.

description: What a spectacular and challenging day.  I took a guided overnight tour that consisted of 3 parts.  A hike to a Karen Hill Tribe village in the mountains outside of Chiang Mai, an overnight stay and a return hike, then a visit to an elephant refuge and finally a float down this beautiful river on a bamboo raft.  That last one was super fun but no pics as I was worried about the phone.  This day was very challenging due to the combination of very significant heat and very steep climbs.  But we were rewarded with beautiful jungle scenery and rice paddies, an amazing waterfall, and finally the tribal village of the Karen people.  THey were very friendly and while very, very rustic the stay was a nice one.

photos.caption: Beautiful rice paddies
Making our way towards the tribal village.  It was insanely hot in the sun and the amount of fluids that poured out of my skin was unbelievable
This saved the day as we cooled off here.  It was an amazing waterfall with a large cave behind it.  We had lunch at this beautiful spot
Sad, little pupper at the lunch stop
Behind the waterfall - generally I turn my nose up at waterfalls these days but this one was exceptional and there were few people around
A rare sighting of me - at the waterfall

Our tour guide Moon as we had lunch.  BTW, those little bananas were insanely good.  Like bananas on steroids.  They were as sweet as a Honeycrisp apple and packed with intense banana flavor.  Incredible.
This local guy was staggering around and finally fully passed out - he was totally stoned
Two nice puppers at the waterfall stop
Continuing our trek to the tribal village.  The heat I tell you, THE HEAT...
Water buffalo being tended by their caretaker.  These animals were suprisingly cute.  I'm mean like way cuter than a cow.
Heading towards the active rice fields of the Karen tribal village
The route was flooded so off with the shoes
Local farmers preparing the rice paddies
Our guide acting as chef for the evening cooking over an open fire
Dinner at our "hotel"

description: We were awakened at 5am by the roosters, dogs, chickens, pigs, and all sorts of activities.  Had a simple breakfast then it was 2 hours of hiking to another waterfall and our final destination.  It was another very hot day with extrememly steep climbs and descents.  The mosquitos were there but not too hectic.  Incredible scenery all around us.  We visited an elephant 'sanctuary' which really is just a money generating business where the elephants are paraded in front of you in close proximity.  Not my favorite sort of enterprise but it was a treat to see an Asian elephant up so close.  Then we went on a river float on bamboo rafts.  Very peaceful with some gentle rapids and a very nice finish to another arduous day.  Look for photo icons to the SW of Chiang Mai if you're interested in seeing where this trek was.

photos.caption: Hiking crew at the start of the 2nd day
Rice paddies along the beautiful trail
It was breathtaking out there
More rice paddies along the way
These were flooded so we had to balance carefully
Behind this view is a beautiful waterfall but who wants to see more waterfall pics?
Our tour guide disappeared for about 20 min as we swam in the pool of the waterfall
Such a beautiful countryside.  After this it was an insanely steep climb and the cooling effect of the swim rapidly vanished
There was an elephant "sanctuary" tagged to the end of the trip.  I mean it is was it is but it was still nice to see an elephant up so close
WTF - at the Chiang Mai Sunday Night Market - a MASSIVE street market, miles long

description: Not too many photos since this was a travel day.  About 4 hours in an utterly packed van filled with young folk and luggage.  It's a fairly dangerous 2-lane road to Pai, filled with huge trucks and blind turns and it rained during the 2nd half so it was a little but of a knuckle-biter.  Pai, as I'm discovering is very, very much a young person town.  And when people say it's a hippie place they really just mean it's a place for getting high.  O guess I should have realized but I just assumed that was like a part of it while I think it's really the main part of it.  So...  I still need to see what kinds of activities more my speed are available - that's my job tomorrow.  I may only be here 3 nights or so - we'll see.

photos.caption: More Khao Soi - more good taste
On the drive from Chiang Mai to Pai
Pai at night
Across the street from my hotel:  3 weed stores side-by-side
My bungalow - it's quite nice

description: It was a slow day today as I really just wanted to relax.  So it's another slow photo day.  Did a little research for tomorrow and for the next transport.  Planning some tours tomorrow.

photos.caption: Place I'm staying at is probably the nicest one so far
Koi pond at my hotel
Another street shot in Pai

description: Did the standard 1/2-day tour in these parts.  A few lame stops but it ended with a few great ones.  There are some really beautiful areas around here and the intermittent rains added to the mood of the place.

photos.caption: Guard dog to the giant buddha.  He's got a little bumhole.
One of the overlooks near Pai
Heading to the requisite waterfall stop

2 minutes after I paid to get in and got to the waterfall, the head honcho came up, waving crazily at these 2 guys on the opposite bank.  It had been raining hard and the water was very rapidly rising.  We all had to get out of there which was a little spooky.
Puppers at the coffee shop stop
Another puppers at the coffee shop stop.  Puppers and coffee - what else can you ask for?
The dogs here are fearless and commonly lay in the road
This place was known as "Bamboo Bridge".  It was a series of well, bamboo bridges, with fantastic views all around
A hut sort of thing at the bamboo bridges
Rice paddies at Bamboo Bridge
More rice paddies at Bamboo Bridge
Rice paddies, etc. at the bamboo bridges
Temple at the bamboo bridges
Pai Canyon, where we were to watch the sunset.  There was to be no sunset, in large part because our tour made us leave before the sunset and also due to the rainy skies
Pai Canyon

description: Another travel day via minivan.  Had to backtrack to Chiang Mai then it was on to Chiang Rai.  Oddly enough, the prior city I was in was Pai and not Chiang Pai.  Why?  Maybe Chiang just wasn't in the picture for the founding.  Or maybe... we just shouldn't ask such questions.

photos.caption: The heavy rains yesterday took their toll on the ride out of Pai.  Mountainsides lost their grip and tumbled onto the 2-lane mountain road
Boulder + mud = boulder on road
A very new buddhist temple in Chiang Rai - super awesome looking
Temple detail
Temple
More temple detail
Detail of a gold temple on the same property
Super cool statue representing who knows what.  Notice the claw coming out at the edge of the water channel.
